raw_text:
Brown names 16 March for Budget
 
 Chancellor Gordon Brown will deliver his Budget to the House of Commons on 16 March, the Treasury has announced.
 
 The Budget, likely to be the last before the General Election, will be at 1230 GMT on that Wednesday, just after Prime Minister's question time. The annual event is when the chancellor outlines the government's taxation and broader economic predictions. It is likely to set out much of the tax and spending battleground for the election, widely expected on 5 May.
 
 Next month's Budget will be Mr Brown's eighth since Labour came to power in 1997. If a May election is called, there could be as little as 18 days between the Budget and the announcement of a date for the election. A shortened Finance Bill would have to be rushed through Parliament with all-party support to allow the Government to continue collecting revenue. The full Finance Bill, with the Budget measures in it, would then be returned to the Commons after the election, if Labour secures another term in office. As Mr Brown announced the Budget date in a short ministerial statement, accountancy firm Ernst & Young urged him to put politics aside and focus on the long-term requirements of the economy. "In the Budgets that were given immediately before the last six elections, taxes were cut by the incumbent chancellor and, in many cases, taxes were increased soon after the election result," said Aidan O'Carroll, E&Y's UK head of tax.
llama3.2:1b: Chancellor Gordon Brown will deliver his Budget to the House of Commons on 16 March at 1230 GMT.
The Budget is likely to be the last before the General Election and sets out major taxation and spending issues for the election in May.

If a May election is called, there could be as little as 18 days between the Budget and the election date, which would require the full Finance Bill to be rushed through Parliament with all-party support.
llama3.2:3b: Chancellor Gordon Brown will deliver his eighth Budget on 16 March to the House of Commons.
The event is likely to outline taxation and economic predictions before a General Election expected on 5 May.

If an election is called soon after, the Finance Bill would need to be rushed through Parliament with all-party support, potentially reducing time between the Budget and election announcement to as little as 18 days.
gemma2:2b: Chancellor Gordon Brown will deliver his Budget on March 16th,  likely to be his last before a General Election.
The Budget will outline government taxation and economic predictions, shaping the upcoming election battleground.
If an early election is called, there may be just 18 days between the Budget and the election announcement.
qwen2.5:0.5b: The Chancellor Gordon Brown will deliver his Budget to Parliament on 16 March.

The Budget is likely to be at 1230 GMT on that Wednesday and set out much of the government's taxation and broader economic predictions for the next financial year, with a significant focus on tax cuts and spending increases that could have wide-ranging implications for elections in May.
It will also mark the end of Prime Minister's questions time.

The Finance Bill is expected to be returned to Parliament after the election, if Labour secures another term in office, but accountancy firm Ernst & Young urged Brown to "put politics aside" and focus on long-term tax planning requirements.
qwen2.5:1.5b: Chancellor Gordon Brown will deliver his 2010 Budget on March 16, coinciding with Prime Minister's question time; likely to set economic and taxation policies for an impending General Election scheduled for May 5th.
qwen2.5:3b: Chancellor Gordon Brown will present his Budget to the House of Commons on 16 March, likely before the May General Election.
This annual event outlines government taxation and economic predictions, crucial for shaping electoral politics.
It is Brown’s eighth Budget since Labour took power in 1997, with a potential election just 18 days away post-Budget.
Ernst & Young urges him to prioritize long-term economic needs over political considerations, citing past precedents where taxes were either cut or increased following elections.
opencoder:1.5b: The output will be a summary text that focuses on key points about the Budget announced by Mr Gordon Brown on 16 March.
It will not include any additional information or reasoning process.
The main aims of the Budget announcement are to inform policymakers and economy stakeholders about future economic and tax policies.
smollm:1.7b: The summary should be concise and to the point, focusing on the key ideas and details of the text.
The goal is to provide a brief overview of the main points without going into too much detail or providing explanations.

Here are some tips to help you achieve this:

1.
**Focus on the main points**: Identify the most important sentences in the text that convey the key information.
These will be the ones that summarize the main ideas and details.
**Use concise language**: Avoid using complex vocabulary or jargon that might confuse readers.
Use simple, clear language to convey your message.
**Keep it brief**: Aim for a summary that is no more than 10% of the original text's length.
This will help you to provide a concise overview without overwhelming readers with too much information.
**Use active voice**: Using active voice makes your writing more engaging and easier to read.
It can also help to create a sense of urgency or importance.
**Remove unnecessary details**: If the text is already brief, there may be no need to include every detail.
Focus on the key points that are essential to understanding the main ideas and details.
**Use bullet points or numbered lists**: If you have multiple items or steps in a process, consider using bullet points or numbered lists to make it easier for readers to follow along.
**Proofread and edit**: Finally, review your summary carefully to ensure that it is free of errors and easy to understand.

Here's an example of how this could be done:

Brown names 16 March for Budget
 
 Chancellor Gordon Brown will deliver his Budget to the House of Commons on 16 March, the Treasury has announced.
The Budget, likely to be the last before the General Election, will be at 1230 GMT on that Wednesday, just after Prime Minister's question time.
The annual event is when the chancellor outlines the government's taxation and broader economic predictions.
It is likely to set out much of the tax and spending battleground for the election, widely expected on 5 May.
Next month's Budget will be Mr Brown's eighth since Labour came to power in 1997.
If a May election is called, there could be as little as 18 days between the Budget and the announcement of a date for the election.
A shortened Finance Bill would have to be rushed through Parliament with all-party support to allow the Government to continue collecting revenue.
The full Finance Bill, with the Budget measures in it, would then be returned to the Commons after the election, if Labour secures another term in office.
As Mr Brown announced the Budget date in a short ministerial statement, accountancy firm Ernst & Young urged him to put politics aside and focus on the long-term requirements of the economy.

"In the Budgets that were given immediately before the last six elections, taxes were cut by the incumbent chancellor and, in many cases, taxes were increased soon after the election," said Aidan O'Carroll, E&Y's UK head of tax.
"If Mr Brown announces the Budget date in a short ministerial statement, accountancy firm Ernst & Young urges him to put politics aside and focus on the long-term requirements of the economy."

The annual event is when the Chancellor outlines government's taxation and broader economic predictions for the election, widely expected on May 5th.

Following next month's Budget, there could be as little as 18 days between its announcement and the election call, with a shorter Finance Bill required to collect revenues while all-party support is needed to allow the Government to continue collecting taxes.
Labour has urged Mr Brown to focus on the long-term needs of the economy in the Budget, while accountancy firm Ernst & Young called for the Chancellor to prioritise this in his upcoming speech.

It is expected to set out much of the government's tax and spending battleground for the May 2015 election.
If an early election occurs, there could be less than 18 days between the Budget announcement and the election date.
A shorter Finance Bill must be rushed through Parliament with all-party support to continue revenue collection.
The full Finance Bill is then returned to the Commons after the election if Labour secures a second term in office.

granite3.1-dense:2b: Chancellor Gordon Brown has scheduled his Budget for 16 March at 1230 GMT during Prime Minister's question time in the House of Commons.

This is Labour's eighth Budget since their 1997 election victory, and it will likely outline the government's taxation and economic strategies, serving as a key election battleground if held on 5 May.

If an early election occurs, there could be just 18 days between the Budget and election announcement, necessitating a shortened Finance Bill for revenue collection continuation with cross-party support.

Accountancy firm Ernst & Young advised Brown to prioritize long-term economic needs over political considerations, noting that incumbent chancellors in the past often reduced taxes before elections and subsequently increased them.

The Budget will outline taxation and economic forecasts, shaping the election debate.
If the election is called in May, a shortened Finance Bill would need swift approval to maintain revenue collection, with the full bill returning post-election if Labour wins.
Ernst & Young urged Brown to prioritize long-term economic needs over political considerations, noting past pre-election tax cuts often followed by post-election increases.
